#Text=Little Bear ( Native American leader )
#Text=Native American Cree leader
#Text=Little Bear
#Text=cabinet portrait from 1906

#Text=Little Bear ( born Ayimâsis or Macquettoquet ) was a Cree leader who lived in the Alberta , Idaho , Montana , and Saskatchewan regions of Canada and the United States , in the 19th and early 20th centuries .
#Text=He is known for his participation in the 1885 North-West Rebellion , which was fought in Alberta and Saskatchewan .
#Text=Early life
#Text=Son of tribal leader Big Bear , his exact date of birth is unknown , but some assume it to be in the mid-1800s .
#Text=One account has him being 43 years old in 1897 , [ 1 ] while another said Little Bear was already in his 70s in 1915 . [ 2 ]
#Text=He may have been born in the early or mid-1840s .
#Text=He was probably living in the Idaho , Montana , and Wyoming region in the 1850s .

#Text=Little Bear said in Butte , Montana in either 1912 or 1913 , that his father lived along the Snake River in Idaho but relocated to the Butte , Montana region to hunt for buffalo and other wild game .
#Text=The Black Hills War
#Text=Little Bear was said to have participated in the Great Sioux War of 1876 or Black Hills War .
#Text=However , nearly all the battles of that war were fought in Montana and northeastern Wyoming .
#Text=After the War , many Cree fled north to Canada and west into British Columbia , Idaho , Oregon , and Washington , but Little Bear and his family continued to live in extreme northern Montana .
#Text=Treaty of Fort Industry

#Text=Apparently , a different native of the name Little Bear was at the 1805 signing of the Treaty of Fort Industry , but this could not have been the Little Bear discussed here as he was not born yet at that time .

#Text=In July 4 , 1805 Little Bear along with leaders from Wyandot , Ottawa , Chipawa , Munsee and Delaware , Shawanee , and Pottawatima nations signed the Treaty of Fort Industry with the United States government at Fort Industry in Ohio .
#Text=This treaty ceded their lands to the US government but allowed for the tribes to continue to hunt and fish in the lands that they formerly owned . [ 3 ] [ 4 ]
#Text=The North-West Rebellion and aftermath
#Text=In early 1885 , the Cree living in central Alberta and central Saskatchewan fought and lost in the North-West Rebellion against Canada .
#Text=Frog Lake Massacre
#Text=During the Rebellion , Wandering Spirit led a group of soldiers — including Little Bear — into attacking the tiny settlement of Frog Lake , Alberta .
#Text=They killed nine Whites in what became known as the Frog Lake Massacre .
#Text=Return to Montana
#Text=After the Rebellion ended , Little Bear and Lucky Man , knowing the Canadian Whites were after them , fled .
#Text=The two gathered many of their people and journeyed back to Montana .
#Text=They slipped through the Babb , Montana region in 1885 and hid out in that region , and then roamed about their original Montana homeland .
#Text=They frequented the land on and around the Flathead Reservation which the Flathead Indians ' agent did not like .
#Text=Little Bear was considered the leader of the Ojibwas of the Basin , Montana region ( southwest Montana ) .
#Text=Deportation
#Text=Montana native and non-native peoples did not welcome Little Bear and his group , saying he had not been born in the United States . [ 5 ]
#Text=They called for Little Bear and the Ojibwas he led to be deported to Canada .
#Text=For the first couple of years after returning to their original Montana homeland , many of Little Bear 's people roamed throughout the vast Blackfeet reservation on the U.S. side of the line .

#Text=In 1888 , the United States reduced the size of the Blackfeet reservation and divided it into three small reservations - the Blackfeet reservation , Fort Belknap reservation , and the Fort Peck reservation .
#Text=Life got harder for Little Bear and his people , and they often went hungry .
#Text=In 1895 , the United States deported Little Bear , Lucky Man and hundreds of other landless Cree and Ojibwas of Montana back to Canada .
#Text=Little Bear and Lucky Man feared the death penalty for their participation in the attacks at Frog Lake .
#Text=When they arrived in Canada , they were apprehended .

#Text=One account has it they stood trial for their part in the Massacre and were acquitted of the charges , while another says no charges were laid against Little Bear as the magistrate said the evidence did not deem charges .

#Text=( It is noticeable that Little Bear is listed among the eight Natives hanged on Nov. 27 , 1885 at Battleford , so perhaps the government did not want the confusion , or mistaken identity to come out in public . )
#Text=Little Bear settled in Canada perhaps at Onion Lake [ 6 ] and in 1898 travelled , with Rev. John McDougall , to Ottawa to complain of the treatment of his people by the government . [ 7 ]
#Text=He soon returned to Montana .
#Text=Efforts to gain a reservation
#Text=Little Bear knew he had to follow the Chippewa leader Rocky Boy if the landless nations of Montana were to gain reservations .
#Text=In 1902 , Rocky Boy and Little Bear attempted to gain either a reservation or tribal recognition on the Flathead reservation .
#Text=The bill to make the Flathead reservation for other landless tribes failed in 1904 .
#Text=In 1905 , 1906 , 1908 , and around 1911 Little Bear contacted Canadian leaders to request land for some of the Cree of Montana .
#Text=At least five First Nations were set aside for the Chippewa of Montana .
#Text=They are the Onion Lake , Samson , Ermineskin , Louis Bull , and Montana First Nations .
#Text=In 1910 Little Bear and his tribe joined the Rocky Boy Reservation . [ 8 ]
#Text=The Babb Chippewa reservation
#Text=In 1909 , the United States set aside a new Chippewa reservation within the Blackfeet reservation , in Montana , between Saint Mary Lake , Babb , and the Canada – US border .
#Text=Chief Rocky Boy was the first to settle there , followed by Little Bear and the people he led .
#Text=In all , around 200 Chippewa and Cree people settled there .
#Text=Rocky Boy reservation
#Text=Since hundreds of Chippewas and Cree continued to remain landless , Rocky Boy and Little Bear stepped up their efforts to get another reservation set aside in Montana .
#Text=Rocky Boy 's brother , Pennahto , told Little Bear to request the old Fort Assiniboine Military Reservation be set aside as a new reservation .
#Text=Neither Pennahto nor Rocky Boy lived to see the establishment of Rocky Boy Reservation .
#Text=After Rocky Boy Reservation was officially established in 1916 , Little Bear became its first Chairman .
#Text=He was already an old man at the time .
#Text=Little Bear died in 1921 , at or nearly eighty years of age .
